snippet: As President Obama announced that $80 million in aid would be available to Michigan, a regional E.P.A. official resigned and a congresswoman announced hearings on the tainted water.
abstract: Susan Hedmen, high-ranking Environmental Protection Agency official, resigns following scrutiny over her failure to respond quickly to concerns about quality of drinking water supply in Flint, Mich; agency administrator Gina McCarthy says she will issue emergency order to expand federal oversight over water quality in Flint, monitoring supply for lead contamination.

byline.contributor: Julie Bosman contributed reporting from Chicago, and Julie Hirschfeld Davis from Washington.

lead_paragraph: As President Obama announced that $80 million in aid would be available to Michigan, a regional E.P.A. official resigned and a congresswoman announced hearings on the tainted water.

headline.main: Flint Fallout: A Resignation, a Hearing and U.S. Aid
headline.print_headline: Flint Fallout: A Resignation and Federal Monitoring
